body:
@piiswrong I did a quick check of this initially but this appears not to be the case. In addition, I was able to validate that the gradients back through some simple tests, using numeric diff, were correct.

I for sure didn't look everywhere so it would be good to get a double check.
LGTM

Please take a look at tools in MXNET_ROOT/tools/.
You can use ImageRecordIter (like training on imagenet) and to the transformations on the fly with symbolic API

@Nzeuwik Thank for the contribution! can you make the enhancement @winstywang mentioned? This would be a great addition to the data loader. please also add your name to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md
This is merge !
@skylook Thanks for your kindness.
@tqchen But I need the real mean value that original image can substract it to help converge.
@piiswrong Do you have time to change the input "data_iter" into .rec file, because that is more intuitive.
You can chang it but i think this is more ubiquitous. Since data iter may do some preprocessing on the data (cropping etc)
@piiswrong When do I use your script? After my train data_iter is defined and then use the script to compute mean file?
i am pr https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/974
Have you tested whether this indeed works with both v3 and v4? Also do we need to check for minor? Is minor always 0 for all v3 and v4 libs?
you means only check MAJOR?
I'm not sure. Does cudnn v3 R1-3 all have minor 0?
+1 for opt

MXNet is based on dmlc's tracking framework, so we should be able to do all launchers, including mpi and yarn. This being said, the launcher.py support might not be up to date to keep all these.

cc @mli  on this
It is highly likely you could use dmlc_mpi.py in tracker folder, as the launcher is a think wrapper of the tracker scripts.
+1 for plugin

CIFAR-10, without CuDNN, with BN

| MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR | Time | Memory | Train Result | Val Result |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | 84.7 sec | 1255 MB | 55.6% | 60.6% |
| 1 | 92.4 sec | 960 MB | 55.6% | 60.6 |

CIFAR-10, with CuDNN, with BN

| MXNET_BACKWARD_DO_MIRROR | Time | Memory | Train Result | Val Result |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| 0 | 46.2 sec | 1286 MB | 55.7% | 66.7% |
| 1 | 53.5 sec | 832 MB | 55.0% | 66.6% |
LGTM, merge first, I will try to fix BN `fix_gamma` today.
Close for Auto Switch PR
I don't think we need to support CuDNN v3 R1-3 because CuDNN v3 Prod is the final product version. Support CuDNN v3 is temporary. I think it is ready to be merged.
I checked V3 prod and V4, and I think this PR is fine.
+1 for plugin
should we close this or keep as a reminder?
+1 for plugin
@FBracun please, don't forget to share your LSTM model in R when it will be done :-)

There is macro bug which travis didn't catch in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/974 .
@yajiedesign @piiswrong Let's use `CUDNN_MAJOR` only for now.
Setting up a https://www.discourse.org/ platform might be a good option to cut down the noise on the github issues.
@vchuravy May I suggest a mailing list / google groups? Allows to stick to an email-based workflow.
I have to say that we have troubles with GCC5 in other Rcpp-realted projects. I am trying to figure out the real reasons.
We just use mpirun to run jobs while does not use any other mpi functions. We found ssh is often more stable than mpirun. Do you have any particular reason to use mpi?
disqus also works with e-mails, but I would be fine with google groups.

Looks good. Some suggestions:
1. We should have something like CppNet in the main repo.
2. Make the json format model file human readable/writable and have a caffe style read and train tool @tqchen is this possible?

I created an op that does this (actually more than this it does sum(input_1*input_2, axis=n)). It didn't seem to generic so I didn't commit it in the main repo. I would be greate if you can remove the prod part and make a SumWithAxis op
The code can be found here: https://gist.github.com/piiswrong/e39f7383cae9d4134f5b

Even if you feed in images of different shape, the network still has fixed shape. You need per example reshape for that, which currently isn't implemented. Also you have to have unified shape within batch in any case

cnn.forward()
copy_cnn_output_to_lstm_intput()
lstm.forward()
lstm.backward()
cnn.backward(lstm.input_grad)

This is basically what you need. You need to modify the call to bind in lstm to make it bind gradient for input
I'm not sure what you mean. Are you saying one batch takes 1s? What's your GPU card? It sounds normal
extension?
@tqchen I think you can group the intermediate node with output and then bind
one pr of image segmentation example is you want,please check #975, but currently it only support     minibatch=1
you can use convolution for that, the num_hidden=1,kernel=(1,1),fix weight=1
Well, when you are runing in a shared mpi cluster, using native scheduler helps you to allocate resources correctly. @mli  we should support this
I guess the point @piiswrong is some big effort and can be done in a separate PR. The general principle is make PR as small as possible so it is clean and easy to review

google groups kind of sucks from China.  I'm kind of pondering whether anyone has ever tried using a reddit subreddit for such a role?  (I've never tried it myself, or seen anyone try it, but the reddit interface is at least relatively lightweight, loads in less than 3 minutes!).  disqus works ok-ish.
OK, merge this in for now. Let us make the non-greyscale on another PR

Just a single image for classification.

I'm testing it without GPU as I'll be running the classification task on SBC like Raspberry Pi or low-end NUC. The 1-sec result of running `MXPredGetOutput` was on an i5 quad-core CPU @ 3.00GHz with ubuntu.

Both mxnet and the cpp example are compiled with O3 optimization.

All other processes like `MXPredForward` `MXPredGetOutputShape` only took a blink on a CPU. Wondering if there's any way to speed up [MXPredGetOutput](http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/doxygen/c__predict__api_8h.html#aeaadef67a6a9a2308f2d8160f91724af), or to just work around it and get the best guess result - and eventually, to find a way to classify image at video rate without GPU.

Any idea would help :+1:

@tqchen , thanks for your replies. I am still trying to launch it with dmlc_mpi.py. Some error info is printed after executing "python  /path-to-mxnet/tracker/dmlc_mpi.py -n 3 -s 3 -H hosts python train_cifar10.py --kv-store dist_sync --model-prefix weights/cifar":

zsh:1: command not found: orted
ORTE was unable to reliably start one or more daemons.
... ...

openmpi is installed in /opt manually and /opt/openmpi/bin is added to PATH in all servers(orted can be executed in all servers). I think this should be some env variable related errors since the default $PATH of a non-interactive+non-login shell(created like "ssh user@remote command") is "/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin".

I have similar errors using ssh but solved it by adding PATH in ['LD_LIBRARY_PATH', 'AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID', 'AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY'], get_env function, dmlc_ssh.py.
I think I should pass PATH, LD_LIBRARY_PATH together to the sub-processes before distributing them to different nodes.

@mli , I have to use a queueing system (torque + maui) to schedule gpu processes from different users in this cluster. One of my friend has launched a mpi version caffe training process like "qsub pbs.job"(to submit the training process). I am not sure if the ssh version mxnet could also work well with this queueing system.

we had a script to launch job by qsub, see 

https://github.com/dmlc/dmlc-core/blob/master/tracker/dmlc_sge.py

the problem is that i slightly changed the `tracker.py`, so i made a separate implementation at ps-lite/tracker while didn't port dmlc_sge.py there yet. i planned to do it next week, and it will be great if you have a test if it is done. but if you need to use it immediately, please consider port dmlc_sge.py into ps-lite/tracker, the change should be minimal.
Thanks. @tornadomeet  Do you have any idea on how to fix weight (without back-propagation update)?
also @mli @hotpxl @jermainewang
cc @piiswrong
Ok. This seems to be a conflict. Symbol also cannot be dumped right? How is it sending those?
Where exactly is the error? Could you compile with debug and trace the error?
This only works if you are trying to sum a 4d tensor along the second dimension though
Pickle can be implemented as long as getstate and setstate are implemented, see https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/symbol.py#L110

```

            mxnet::Executor::Bind(sym_out, ctx_dev, g2c, in_args, arg_grad_store,
            grad_req_type,aux_states);
```

@zhubuntu 
Two problems here.
First, the shape is wrong. Try using infer-shape.
Second, when you use BatchNorm operator, you'll need the aux_states.

refer to new PR https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/980

For now, if you want to use cpp, you have to check the code carefully.
I mean, you have to be familiar with the source codes in some degree, if you want to add something new.

Operator to do sum (and other operate) in axis should be quite usefull.

@zhangchen-qinyinghua Ok,I'll see if I can run it tomorrow.It's time to prepare the exam.
You need to install protobuf compiler.
It seems is about your network and optimization problem. Try normalization of input, different optimizer, and different learning rate
In bind symbol process, the input shape is fixed to [nbatch, channel, h, w] or [nbatch, ndim]. It you want to predict on different batch size, you need to bind again with new shape.

There can be many reason.
1. How is your network? If network is a bottle neck, it will be slow.
2. What is your batch size? If your batch size is too small, it will be slow.
3. How is your PCI-Bandit? Default kvstore is on CPU, which will copy GPU to CPU then update. If your PCI-Bandit is limited, you can try sync on device.
There is a change of iterator interface, but I didn't have time to fix the example yet. I will try to fix it in tomorrow.
ps-lite will build protobuf automatically. this bug seems due to someone updated ps-lite into not well tested version. i made a quick fix, please `git pull` and `git submodule update` and then build

your performance number is abnormal. please have look at the [performance note](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification#note-on-performance) to see whether or not it solves your problem
change https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/elementwise_binary_scalar_op-inl.h#L255 to `return param_.__DICT__();`

Thanks! I managed to make it work for a GPU cluster.
FYI, I had to change the code a bit from ../../tools/launch.py to ../mxnet/tools/launch.py

I don't think it comes from the S3 connection because I get the same error when using data_dir = '/home/ubuntu/mnist'
Was due to the recent update of data iter interface, need to add name to final softmax layer.

i suggest to use examples in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/example/image-classification

the end-to-end examples under tests/ are not tested for some days,
Ok, thanks :)

You can fix the problem by adding parameter `name` to the final layer.
e.g.

``` python
final_net = Softmax(in, name='softmax')
```

Please see if it solves your problem, and submit a PR if you fixed it :)
It worked, thanks for your help! I submitted a new PR.
@antinucleon Appreciate for you guys fantastic work ^_^

By replacing {} with "std::unordered_set<uint32_t>()" in graph_executor.cc and static_graph.h, I successfully compiled mxnet.


This might have been caused by different layout of structures between the
DLL and the EXE. With different compile options, the compiler might layout
the struct/class in different ways, creating incompatible code. There are
two ways to avoid this: 1) use only C api in the dll. 2) compile the exe
directly, instead of generating DLL and then link into EXE

I would like to suggest we take 1, since we will then just offer binary
distribution of the DLL, just as we did with Python and R.

with 16 gpus you probably need an even bigger batch size
please try to use the largest batch size which can fit into gpu memory (look it by `nvidia-smi`)
Thanks a lot. I achieve 142 samples/sec by using a batch size of 512.
@winstywang can you review this?
One question: Can we reuse(or enhance) the model.fit for fcn training? instead of using the current solver?

Just want  to confirm if CuDNN update the moving statistics in forward instead of backward, this might affect the advanced mode for the memory optimization, so maybe we want to disable it for now if there is no significant speed gain.

Currently it's registered as a separate op anyway because it's not compatible with the original interface.

and moving_mean is in aux. why does it matter?

@piiswrong In the advanced mode, bn forward will be called many times. BTW, I notice CuDNN Activation costs more memory and a little bit slower. We may consider a better way to make choice of CuDNN or our implementation.

Ok I get what you mean. I think cudnn batch norm should be good. At least it saves memory for out_affine. Cudnn Act might be slower because it depends on input on backward.

BTW, if you are calling multiple times dropout wouldn't work either right? Basically anything with mutable states in forward doesn't work
